context.text: In [3], the Hopfield-like network analysis and computer simulations showed that an attractor neural network is capable of performing a Boolean factor analysis of real data.
In cases of large dimensionality, it was a challenge [3] to develop the Hopfield-like neural–network–based algorithm for Boolean factor analysis.

As show in [3], this ability mainly depends on two network parameters: the sparseness of factor encoding and the relative informational loading \$L/N\$ where \$N\$ is the dimensionality of the signal space and at the same time the total number of neurons.
As shown in [3], this choice of activation threshold enables the network activity to stabilize in point or cyclic attractors of length two.
In [3]–[6] and [20], we have shown that a Hopfield-like neural network is capable of performing Boolean factor analysis of high-dimension signals.
According to [3], the Lyapunov function value for each factor is almost proportional to the number of input patterns which contain it.

It has been noted [3], [20] that in ordinary stochastic HDP critic training the total gradient of the averaged squared Bellman error (\$\langle E^{2} \rangle = \langle (U+\gamma J_{1} - J_{0})^{2} \rangle \$) may in fact converge to the wrong parameters, whereas the partial gradient \$ {{ \partial \langle E^{2} \rangle }/ { \partial {\bf w}_{c}}} =-2 \langle E ({{ \partial J_{0}}/ { \partial {\bf w}_{c}}}) \rangle \$ achieves the correct values.33In [20], the methods of using partial and total gradient are called one-gradient and two-gradient rules, respectively, because when using the total gradient, the term \$\gamma {({ \partial J_{1}}/{ \partial {\bf w}_{c}})}\$ is added.

An alternative for the total gradient to yield correct critic parameters would be to use the two-sample rule [21], [13], [3], [20] to avoid correlation of the error \$E\$ with the gradient \$ {{ dE}/ { d{\bf w}_{c}}}\$ two trajectories based on the noisy system equations (\${\bf {\mathdot {x}}}={\bf f}({\bf x},{\bf u})+ \mmb{\nu } \$) with different noise realizations \$ \mmb{\nu } \$, such that \$\langle E {({ dE}/ { d{\bf w}_{c}})} \rangle =0\$.

context.text: Implementation of neural networks (NNs) can be accomplished using either analog or digital hardware [5].
On the other hand, analog systems are more difficult to be designed and can only be feasible for large scale productions, or for very specific applications [5].

The digital NN hardware implementations are further classified as follows: 1) field-programmable gate array (FPGA)-based implementations, 2) digital signal processor (DSP)-based implementations, and 3) application specific integrated chip (ASIC)-based implementations [5], [6].

context.text: Among them, the \$\nu\$-SVM [10] and the “sparse” SVMs described in [5] maintain the property that the hidden-layer weights \$\{\omega_{k}\}_{k=1}^N\$ are a subset of the data.
For SVMs, several approaches are tested, namely, the standard one-norm soft margin SVM, the \$\nu\$-SVM [10], and the greedy (forward) selection of support vectors presented in [5].
Regarding the number of support vectors, sequential FNNs constructed models with less hidden units than standard SVMs (including \$\nu\$-SVMs), and in the same range as the method presented in [5].
The method described in [5] performs a greedy (forward) selection of the support vectors, together with an efficient computation of the vector \$(\alpha_i)\$ for the two-norm soft margin SVM.
For SVMs, we tested the standard one-norm soft margin SVM, the \$\nu\$-SVM [10], and the SVMRC [5] (with \$\kappa = 59\$ and the rest of parameters to their default value).

context.text: The underlying principle is closely related to that of the recently proposed QPSK receivers in [5]–[7] and shown experimentally in [8].

Here we provide an alternative implementation for practical advanced differential phase transmission, trading-off the electronic complexity in [5]–[8] for optical complexity, taking advantage of the fact that optics may be more adept than electronics at ultrahigh-speed (40–160 Gb/s) processing.

The new system approaches coherent homodyne performance to within 0.3 dB, providing a venue for alternative high-speed optical implementation of the electronic postprocessing concepts proposed in [5]–[7] and experimentally demonstrated using off-line electronic-domain digital signal processing in [8].

context.text: Previous studies of variation in plasma etching have examined microloading due to pattern density and reactive ion etch (RIE) lag [aspect ratio dependent etching (ARDE)], generally treating these as distinct causes of etch nonuniformity for individual features [1]–[2][4].

The mechanism by which pattern density influences etch rate is assumed to be through the depletion or consumption of reactant species [2], [6], [8], similar to the approach of Hill et al. where diffusion of reactants that are perturbed by pattern density lead to reduction of the reactant concentration in DRIE [6].
During the etch process we assume that the limiting factor is the chemical species that reacts with the wafer surface [2].
Gottscho has shown that overall etch rate is dependent on a synergistic relationship between ion and neutral flux [2].
Transport kinetics of ions and reactive neutrals are believed to be the primary physical cause of feature aspect ratio or RIE lag dependencies [2]–[4].
Furthermore, the CW model makes the assumption that etch rates will be proportional to the flux of etching species [2], [4].

context.text: Previous studies of variation in plasma etching have examined microloading due to pattern density and reactive ion etch (RIE) lag [aspect ratio dependent etching (ARDE)], generally treating these as distinct causes of etch nonuniformity for individual features [1]–[4].
Transport kinetics of ions and reactive neutrals are believed to be the primary physical cause of feature aspect ratio or RIE lag dependencies [2]–[4].
Our feature level model implements the Coburn and Winters (CW) model [4], which applies the theory of Knudsen transport to the etch process.
Furthermore, the CW model makes the assumption that etch rates will be proportional to the flux of etching species [2], [4].

context.text: This safe shoot-through feature in turn allows the inverter to operate without dead-time protection, hence gives rise to a more accurate output waveform quality and lesser common-mode complications, as discussed in [5] and [6].
In this work, all PWM schemes for Z-source NPC inverter are developed from basic three-level modulation concepts presented in [6] and [7] using the 2-D vectorial representation shown in Fig. 2.
According to [6] and [7], three-level inverter modulation can be viewed as a two-level modulation problem after an “origin-shifting” transformation is performed.

For minimizing the inverter output distortion, a triplen offset can also be added to the sinusoidal references for equalizing the E-null states at the start and end of each half carrier cycle [6], [8].

For comparison, the reference/carrier arrangement and state sequence for a conventional NPC inverter are also shown in the figure with a noted feature being that the E-null states at the start and end of each half carrier cycle are again kept constant for optimal harmonic performance [6], [8].

Instead, this subsection focuses on the appropriate insertion of shoot-through states to the origin-shifted 60 °-discontinuous concept reported in [6] to study another possible PWM scheme with reduced common mode switching for Z-source NPC control.

According to [6], origin-shifted 60 °-discontinuous PWM is realized by first shifting the origin from \$(\{-{\hbox{1}},-{\hbox{1}},-{\hbox{1}}\}; \{{\hbox{0,0,0}}\}; \{{\hbox{1,1,1}}\})\$ to \$(\{{\hbox{0}},-{\hbox{1}},-{\hbox{1}}{\}}; \{{\hbox{1,0,0}}\})\$, as indicated in Fig. 2 for an example, before applying the 60 °-discontinuous magnitude test to the effective reference phasor for deriving the required triplen offset \$V_{{\rm off}(os - 60^{\circ})}\$, whose expression can be found in [6].
Using \$V_{{\rm off}(os - 60^{\circ})}\$ and according to [6], the inverter generated common mode voltage is then always confined below one-third of the dc link voltage.

context.text: Many hardware implementations of ECC have been proposed [3]–[7][12].
Most of the proposed processors that support general curves over \${\rm GF}(p)\$ are multiplier-based [7], [11], [12].
The processors proposed in [7], [11], [12] are based on nonsystolic multipliers.
The processor in [7] employs an optimized 64 \$\times\$ 64-bit multiplier and the reported result is typical of multiplier-based standard-cell designs.
By pipelining the multiplier, this design improves the performance of the architecture presented in [7] at the expense of hardware area.

A performance comparison between our processor and the processor in [7] under a similar condition shows that our processor can run at a higher frequency but requires more cycles per computation due to the finely pipelined carry chain, and that in total our processor is 2.5 times faster.

references.text: S. B. rs, L. Batina, B. Preneel and J. Vandewalle, "Hardware implementation of an elliptic curve processor over \${rm GF}(p)\$", Proc. 14th IEEE Int. Conf. Application-Specific Systems Architectures and Processors (ASAP '03), pp. 433-443, 2003-Jun.
references.title:
Hardware implementation of an elliptic curve
processor over  <ref_formula><tex>${\rm GF}(p)$</tex></ref_formula>

context.text: Many hardware implementations of ECC have been proposed [3]–[8][12].
Recently, another architecture of ECC processor that is based on a systolic arithmetic unit appeared in the literature [8], [10].

In [8] the processor for general curves over \${\rm GF}(p)\$ is built on a systolic array for Montgomery modular multiplication, and in [10] the processor for general curves over \${\rm GF}(2^{n})\$ is built on a systolic array for both multiplication and division.
In [8], although the systolic array exhibits a high inherent throughput, the processor suffers from the system-level performance degradation due to the inefficient utilization of the array.
It is the processor described in [8], which employs a linear systolic array for Montgomery modular multiplication.
The processor in [8] requires much more cycles than ours, which is primarily due to two factors.

context.text: Many hardware implementations of ECC have been proposed [3]–[11][12].
Most of the proposed processors that support general curves over \${\rm GF}(p)\$ are multiplier-based [7], [11], [12].
The processors proposed in [7], [11], [12] are based on nonsystolic multipliers.
The design in [11] is an extension to a Sparc processor using a fully-pipelined 64 \$\times\$ 64-bit multiplier.
The processors based on nonsystolic multipliers except for that in [11] require less cycles than ours, but operate at accordingly lower frequencies and thus have lower overall performances.
The processor in [11] is 4 times faster than ours.

context.text: Many hardware implementations of ECC have been proposed [3]–[12].
Most of the proposed processors that support general curves over \${\rm GF}(p)\$ are multiplier-based [7], [11], [12].
The processors proposed in [7], [11], [12] are based on nonsystolic multipliers.
The processor in [12] employs a full-word multiplier that is built on the embedded multipliers and the fast carry look-ahead logic on the adopted FPGAs.

context.text: At this purpose, compensation of three stage amplifiers, where the second stage is the only noninverting one, is traditionally obtained through the nested Miller compensation (NMC) technique [1]–[4][5].
When the inner OTA stage is the only inverting one, another kind of compensation scheme, termed the reversed NMC (RNMC), is the most suitable option [4], [5], [18]–[22].

This technique exploits the same operating principle of the NMC but provides an inherent bandwidth improvement since, as shown in Fig. 1, the inner compensation capacitor does not load the output node [4], [20].

Galton presented the tree-structured DAC architecture along with two special-case configurations that achieve first-order and second-order noise shaping, respectively [5]–[9].
In order to spectrally shape the circuit errors in a DAC, the tree-structured DAC requires each of its switching blocks to generate a high-pass switching sequence \$s_{k,r}\$ \$(n)\$ [5].
As shown in [5], the DAC noise is a linear combination of the switching sequences.

references.text: J. Welz and I. Galton, "Simplified logic for first order and second order mismatch-shaping digital-to-analog converters", IEEE Trans. Circuits Syst. II Analog Digit. Signal Process., vol. 48, no. 11, pp. 1014-1026, Nov. 2001.
references.title: Simplified logic for first order and second order mismatch-shaping digital-to-analog converters

context.text: Galton presented the tree-structured DAC architecture along with two special-case configurations that achieve first-order and second-order noise shaping, respectively [5]–[6][9].

A conventional dithering technique is employed to suppress spurious tones in previous work [6], [7] where a linear feedback shift register (LFSR) is used to generate a pseudorandom binary sequence (PRBS) as the dither sequence.

The second-order mismatch-shaping configuration, on the other hand, is much less prone to yielding spurious tones and also gives an improved SNDR, but the improvement comes at a higher hardware cost [6], [8].

In theory [6], to produce such a switching sequence, the first-sum sequence \$\alpha_{1}\$ \$(n)\$, defined as the summation of \$s_{k,r}\$ \$(i)\$ from \$i = 0\$ to \$n -1\$, has to be a bounded sequence.

When \$q \ne 0\$, our sequencing logic is similar to the second-order sequencing logic with \$M\$-state accumulator being limited to three values 1, 0, and \$-1\$ (i.e., \$M =3\$) [6], where the hardware cost is low but the excessive saturation of the \$M\$-state accumulator leads to first-order noise shaping.

However, the proposed sequencing logic in Fig. 4 will produce exactly the same results as the second-order sequencing logic [6] does if the \$M\$-state accumulator is enabled only when the output of the 3-state accumulator and the parity sequence are both 1.

context.text: Recently, several nonlinear techniques based on neural networks [9]–[10][17] have been developed for designing different kinds of FIR filters.
The representative technique in [10] constructs the energy function of the network coincides with the error function of the filter design.
It is clear that the proposed neural structure is much simpler and the number of neurons required is significantly reduced to compare with the previous neural-based method [10].
This is due to the fact that the number of neurons required in our technique is only proportional to the filter length \$N\$, instead of the sampling grid \$L\$, as required in [10].
The proposed method achieves the same results as those of the previous neural-based method [10] and the conventional least-squares method.
As observed from Fig. 3, the performance for the proposed approach is better than that for the Bhattacharya–Antoniou method [10].
The maximum peak errors obtained by our technique are superior to the method of [10] and the conventional least-squares method.
The computational requirement (i.e., MFLOPS) and the required number of neurons in our technique are significantly smaller than that of the Bhattacharya–Antoniou method [10].

In order to compare the increasing-rate of the computational requirement of the proposed technique with the previous neural-based method [10], the specifications of filter with \$\omega_{k} = 0.24\ \pi, \quad L + 1 = 4N\$ and varying filter length for \$N=31\$ to 71 are designed.

context.text: In the last decade, Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT) [1] has been successfully used in a wide range of applications, including numerical analysis, signal analysis, image and video coding, pattern recognition, statistics, and physics.
As a generalization of DWT, discrete wavelet packet transform (DWPT) provides good temporal and spectral resolutions in arbitrary regions of the time and frequency (TF) plane [1], [2].

Due to the characteristic of flexible TF decomposition, DWPT has also been widely used in many applications, especially in image and video coding, speech and audio coding, speech enhancement, speech recognition, hearing aid and digital communications [1], [3]–[6].
In practice, DWT and DWPT are often implemented by a tree-structured filterbank [1].

context.text: Trenas' method [8] exploits the in-place nature of the DWPT algorithm and uses a single processing element (PE) consisting of \$L\$ multipliers in parallel and \$L - 1\$ adders for each low-pass and high-pass filters (\$L\$ is the number of filter taps) to increase the throughput.

Since \$L\$-2 samples are shared by the input sequences to every two consecutive butterflies (e.g., \$G_{0, 0}\$ and \$G_{0, 1}\$ at level 1) in the same group, the shared data can be buffered by extra storage provided by the butterflies [8].
[8] and Aroutchelvame and Raahemifar single PE methods [11] have a long processing time especially for high-level DWPT.
